articles.title: NASA Continues Search for Moon-Focused Sustainability Solutions
articles.summary: NASA is accepting U.S. submissions for the second phase of the agency’s LunaRecycle Challenge, a Moon-focused recycling competition. articles.content:
An artist’s concept of the Moon (right) and Mars (center) against the starry expanse of space. A sliver of the Earth’s horizon can be seen in the foreground. Credit: NASA

NASA is accepting U.S. submissions for the second phase of the agency’s LunaRecycle Challenge, a Moon-focused recycling competition. The challenge aims to develop solutions for recycling common trash materials – like fabrics, plastics, foam, and metals – that could accumulate from activities such as system operations, industrial activities, and building habitats in deep space.

Phase 2 of the LunaRecycle Challenge is divided into two levels: a milestone round and the final round. Submissions for the milestone round are open until January 2026, with finalists from that round announced in February. Up to 20 finalists from the milestone round will compete in the challenge’s in-person prototype demonstrations and final judging, slated for the following August. Cash prizes totaling $2 million are available for successful solutions in both rounds.

“NASA is eager to see how reimagining these materials can be helpful to potential future planetary surface missions,” said Jennifer Edmunson, acting program manager for Centennial Challenges at NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama. “I’m confident focusing on the most critical trash items – and integration of the prototype and digital twin competition tracks – will yield remarkable solutions that could enable a sustainable human presence off-Earth and transform the future of space exploration.”

Estimates indicate a crew of four astronauts could generate more than 2,100 kilograms (4,600 pounds) of single-use waste – including food packaging, plastic films, foam packaging, clothing, and more – within 365 days. Successful solutions in LunaRecycle’s Phase 2 should manage realistic trash volumes while minimizing resource inputs and crew time and operating safely with minimal hazards.

Phase 2 is only open to U.S. individuals and teams. Participants can submit solutions regardless of whether they competed in the earlier Phase 1 competition.

All Phase 2 participants are expected to build a physical prototype. In addition, participants can submit a digital twin of their prototype for additional awards in the milestone and final rounds.

The LunaRecycle Challenge is a NASA Centennial Challenge, part of the Prizes, Challenges and Crowdsourcing Program within NASA’s Space Technology Mission Directorate. LunaRecycle Phase 1 received record-breaking interest from the global innovator community. The challenge received more than 1,200 registrations – more than any competition in the 20-year history of Centennial Challenges – and a panel of 50 judges evaluated nearly 200 submissions. Seventeen teams were selected as Phase 1 winners, representing five countries and nine U.S. states. Winners were announced via livestream on NASA Marshall’s YouTube channel.

LunaRecycle is managed at NASA Marshall with subject matter experts primarily at the center, as well as NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida and NASA’s Ames Research Center in California’s Silicon Valley. NASA, in partnership with The University of Alabama College of Engineering, manages the challenge with coordination from former Centennial Challenge winner AI SpaceFactory and environmental sustainability industry member Veolia.

To learn more about LunaRecycle’s second phase, including registration for upcoming webinars, visit:

https://www.nasa.gov/lunarecycle

-end-

articles.personality_title: NASA launches new phase of LunaRecycle Challenge to tackle space waste
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA is working on ways to handle trash that astronauts create during space missions. When people live and work on the Moon or other planets, they will produce waste like plastics, fabrics, and metals. Managing this trash is important for keeping space habitats clean and safe.

**What happened** – NASA has opened submissions for the second phase of its LunaRecycle Challenge, a competition focused on recycling trash materials from space missions. This phase has two parts: a milestone round ending in January 2026 and a final round in August 2026. Up to 20 teams will show their prototypes in person. Winners can earn a share of $2 million in prizes. The challenge is open to U.S. individuals and teams, even if they didn’t join the first phase.

**Impact** – This challenge is important because astronauts may produce over 2,100 kilograms (4,600 pounds) of waste in one year. Finding ways to recycle this waste means fewer supplies need to be sent from Earth, saving money and resources. It also helps create a cleaner, safer environment for future space missions. The competition encourages new ideas to make space exploration more sustainable.

**What's next step** – Teams will develop physical prototypes of their recycling ideas and can also create digital versions called digital twins for extra awards. NASA will select finalists in early 2026, who will then demonstrate their solutions in August 2026. The results could lead to real recycling systems used in deep space missions.

**One-sentence takeaway** – NASA’s LunaRecycle Challenge invites innovators to create recycling solutions that could help astronauts manage waste and support long-term space exploration.
articles.personality_title_fr: La NASA lance une nouvelle phase du défi LunaRecycle pour gérer les déchets spatiaux
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La NASA cherche des solutions pour gérer les déchets produits par les astronautes lors des missions spatiales. Quand des humains vivront et travailleront sur la Lune ou d'autres planètes, ils généreront des déchets comme des plastiques, tissus et métaux. Gérer ces déchets est essentiel pour garder les habitats spatiaux propres et sûrs.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – La NASA a ouvert les inscriptions pour la deuxième phase du défi LunaRecycle, une compétition axée sur le recyclage des déchets issus des missions spatiales. Cette phase comprend deux étapes : une étape intermédiaire jusqu'en janvier 2026 et une finale en août 2026. Jusqu'à 20 équipes présenteront leurs prototypes en personne. Les gagnants peuvent remporter une part des 2 millions de dollars de prix. La compétition est ouverte aux individus et équipes américaines, même s'ils n'ont pas participé à la première phase.

**Impact** – Ce défi est important car un équipage d'astronautes peut produire plus de 2 100 kilogrammes (4 600 livres) de déchets en un an. Trouver des moyens de recycler ces déchets permet de réduire la quantité de matériel à envoyer depuis la Terre, ce qui économise des ressources et de l'argent. Cela aide aussi à créer un environnement plus propre et plus sûr pour les futures missions spatiales. La compétition stimule de nouvelles idées pour rendre l'exploration spatiale plus durable.

**Prochaine étape** – Les équipes devront créer des prototypes physiques de leurs idées de recyclage et peuvent aussi réaliser des versions numériques appelées « jumeaux numériques » pour des prix supplémentaires. La NASA sélectionnera les finalistes début 2026, qui présenteront ensuite leurs solutions en août 2026. Ces résultats pourraient aboutir à des systèmes de recyclage utilisés dans les missions spatiales.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le défi LunaRecycle de la NASA invite les innovateurs à créer des solutions de recyclage pour aider les astronautes à gérer leurs déchets et soutenir l'exploration spatiale à long terme.
articles.personality_title_es: La NASA lanza una nueva fase del reto LunaRecycle para gestionar residuos espaciales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La NASA está buscando formas de manejar la basura que los astronautas generan durante las misiones espaciales. Cuando personas vivan y trabajen en la Luna u otros planetas, producirán desechos como plásticos, telas y metales. Controlar esta basura es clave para mantener los hábitats espaciales limpios y seguros.

**Qué pasó** – La NASA abrió las inscripciones para la segunda fase del reto LunaRecycle, una competencia enfocada en reciclar materiales de desecho de misiones espaciales. Esta fase tiene dos etapas: una ronda de hitos que termina en enero de 2026 y una ronda final en agosto de 2026. Hasta 20 equipos mostrarán sus prototipos en persona. Los ganadores pueden repartir 2 millones de dólares en premios. La competencia está abierta a individuos y equipos de EE.UU., incluso si no participaron en la primera fase.

**Impacto** – Este reto es importante porque cuatro astronautas pueden generar más de 2,100 kilogramos (4,600 libras) de basura en un año. Encontrar formas de reciclar estos desechos significa enviar menos suministros desde la Tierra, ahorrando recursos y dinero. También ayuda a crear un ambiente más limpio y seguro para futuras misiones espaciales. La competencia fomenta nuevas ideas para hacer que la exploración espacial sea más sostenible.

**Próximo paso** – Los equipos deberán construir prototipos físicos de sus ideas de reciclaje y también pueden hacer versiones digitales llamadas gemelos digitales para premios adicionales. La NASA seleccionará finalistas a principios de 2026, quienes luego demostrarán sus soluciones en agosto de 2026. Los resultados podrían conducir a sistemas reales de reciclaje usados en misiones espaciales.

**Conclusión en una frase** – El reto LunaRecycle de la NASA invita a innovadores a crear soluciones de reciclaje para ayudar a los astronautas a manejar la basura y apoyar la exploración espacial a largo plazo.
